title: 106_hr4800
content: The Act may be cited as the "Ronald Reagan Memorial Act of 2000". The Congress recognizes Ronald Reagan as an American hero for his policies that won the Cold War, restored freedom and democracy, lowered taxes, and brought peace and prosperity. His legacies include restoring faith in democracy and capitalism, pride in being American, and renewing the honor of the Presidency, deserving national recognition. Former President Ronald Reagan's contributions as a preeminent American statesman and one of the greatest Presidents deserve permanent memorialization alongside other American leaders on the Mall in Washington, D.C. Authorization of Ronald Reagan Memorial on the Mall in Washington, D.C. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission is authorized to establish the Ronald Reagan Memorial on Federal lands in Washington, D.C. The memorial will be located west of the Capitol and east of the Lincoln Memorial, within Area I as defined by the Commemorative Works Act. The National Capital Memorial Commission and the Secretary of the Interior will assist the Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission in their duties. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission is tasked with recommending a permanent location and selecting a design for the memorial. The Secretary of the Interior will provide necessary support staff to assist the commission. The process of recommending a location and selecting a design must begin within six months of the Act's enactment. The Secretary will erect a marker at the approved site designating it as the "Future Site of the Ronald Reagan Memorial." The marker for the Ronald Reagan Memorial must be installed within 3 months of the law's approval, be at least 3 feet square, and maintained by the Secretary until the memorial is completed. Certain sections of the Commemorative Works Act do not apply to this memorial. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission is established. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission is established as a commission comprised of members appointed by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the majority leader of the Senate. The commission is chaired by one of its members designated jointly by the Speaker of the House of Representatives and the majority leader of the Senate. Meetings are scheduled no later than one month after members are appointed and as necessary. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission, appointed by congressional leaders, is tasked with raising funds, selecting a design, and recommending a location for the memorial. It is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act and must issue regular reports to Congress and the President. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission, appointed by congressional leaders, is responsible for selecting a design and recommending a location for the memorial by February 6, 2002. The Ronald Reagan Memorial Commission is tasked with selecting a design and location for the memorial authorized by this Act. The Secretary of the Interior is defined as the "Secretary" in this Act.
